title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: As we reached the Broomhill road we metMrs. Stewart of Greenknowe, her daughter Mary, andLily Easton, the youngest daughter of the farmer ofBlinkbonny Mains—one of the largest farms in theparish. The farmhouse was an old mansion-house,and was situated about two miles to the north-east ofthe village.

snippet: Accordingly Willie went to the church of hisfathers, the Auld Licht Antiburgher Church of Broomhill, and the first thing he heard was the precentorreading that " the prayrers of this congregation arerequested for a member in sore trouble, and for hisafflicted famdy."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " I'll go with you," said Mr. M'Nab, glad to havesuch an unexpected chance of meeting Miss Stewart;and, as they had reached the Broomhill road beforeshe was at the Knowe gate, Jamie pointed out the" Fillies' Bridge," the " dookin' pool at the crook 0' theden," and other objects of interest. He seized hisbonnet as Miss Stewart approached, and pulled hishead with it so as to make a very low bow, all thetime grinning from ear to ear; and, after answering herinquiries about the little ones, he made a low bow toeach of them and was off, still grinning with delight.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition

snippet: I took a walk up to the Knowe here togather fir-taps for my mother to kin'le the fire wi';she says it's owre warm to keep it in a' nicht, an' thefir-taps has rozet (rosin) in them, an' they're grand forkin'lin' a fire after they're dried; this is a pockfu' 0'them; an' good-bye, sir. I wad like to be at theBroomhill road afore Miss Stewart passes. She kensme, an' aye speaks awfu' nice to me."

snippet: On a fine morning in the autumn of 1836,Strachan Gemmell, with a dingy shepherd's plaidround his neck and a staff in his hand, was stridingalong the Broomhill road, followed at a short distanceby Big Murray, who carried a large smoothing-iron,better known as a " tailor's goose," under the one arm,and a piece of smooth tapered wood about a yardin length, called a lap-board or " la'brod," underthe other.
